You said this 24:15 is not proven. I literally just proved it on a tissue in like 30 seconds for the positive integers. All even numbers can be written as 2k for k being natural. Every even larger than 2 therefore can be written as 2(k+1). Let k=1 and we have that 4 is the sum of 2 and 2 which are primes. Now assume the proposition is true for k. Then 2(k+1) = SUM(primes). Now for the k+1'th case, we have 2((k+1)+1)= 2(k+1)+2=SUM(primes) +2 , which is the sum of some primes plus 2 which is a prime, so it's a sum of primes. So if it's true for k it's also true for k+1, and we shown in the beginning it's true for 1. let k be one and its true for k+1=2, now let k be 2 and its true for 3, and so on and so on until we see it's true for all positive integers.

The completeness of an axiom, within the context of mathematical logic and formal systems, conveys the property by which an axiomatization or formal theory is endowed with the capacity to fully capture or exhaustively encompass the entirety of all mathematical truths or propositions that can be expressed or deduced within its designated language or structure, such that no additional axioms or rules of inference are required to ascertain the truth or falsehood of every conceivable statement expressible within that system, thereby demonstrating a thorough and unambiguous coverage of the mathematical landscape without any lacunae.

A mathematical proof is a formal, deductive exposition employing axiomatic systems and first-order predicate logic, whereby a proposition or theorem is demonstrated to be an inescapable and valid consequence, with absolute certainty, through a sequence of meticulously constructed and unassailable logical arguments, resting upon self-evident axioms and established lemmata, thereby rendering it impervious to refutation and incontrovertibly affirming the veracity of the enunciated mathematical statement within the confines of the chosen formal framework.

"∃" is the existential quantifier in formal logic. It denotes the existence of at least one element or individual within a defined context. When utilized in logical expressions, it indicates that there is, indeed, an element meeting the specified condition or statement. This quantifier plays a crucial role in predicate logic and mathematical reasoning, enabling us to address the presence of specific elements that fulfill certain criteria.

∀,  represents the universal quantifier in formal logic. It symbolizes "for all" or "for every" in a given context. When used in a logical expression, it signifies that a statement or condition holds true for all elements or individuals within a specified domain. It is a fundamental component of predicate logic and mathematical reasoning, allowing us to make generalized statements about entire sets or collections.

A proposition is a declarative statement or claim that can be evaluated as either true or false, often serving as a fundamental unit of logical analysis and communication in various fields, including mathematics, philosophy, and science. It is, in essence, a statement open to logical examination and verification.

To ascertain truth, one must engage in a systematic and analytical process of empirical observation, logical reasoning, and the application of established principles and axioms. This process involves collecting and evaluating data, conducting rigorous analysis, and ensuring internal consistency in one's conclusions. Truth is a result of a relentless pursuit of accuracy and the relentless commitment to logical integrity.

21:55  I have a solution to 4 color theorem. The minimum number of sides needed to create an area is three, that is a triangle. In a four color theorem whenever you must have a fourth color, you end up enclosing at least one color, could be two or even three. So when a fourth color is deployed at least one color gets enclosed and becomes available for next round. This way you will never need a fifth color because when fourth color is required there is one available. Forgot to mention this, four colors are needed because triangle has three sides and the color in the middle, four colors are all you need and fourth color gets enclosed. For three dimension you need five colors, four surfaces of pyramid and fifth is volume enclosed in the middle.

@wingman4668  Harder than Harvard in what? MIT is more rigorous than Harvard in highly technical subjects (ie computer science). Harvard Business or Law is top of the line. MIT doesn't even have a law school, and its business school is tech oriented.  Ultimately these are two vastly different universities.
@themaskedman221  OH THANKS MR KNOW IT ALL. An answer would've been good too

@wingman4668  Don't ask questions if you're looking for specific answers. You will, more often than not, end up disappointed.  The answer to the question is that the comparison is meaningless. You're comparing a polytechnic university to a traditional research university. That doesn't make any sense.  If you had compared MIT to Georgia Tech (which is an apt comparison), I'd have told you that MIT is the more rigorous school.
@wingman4668   He answered the question quite well. The problem is your limited reading comprehension.
@themaskedman221  can u please elaborate on what do u mean by 'polytechnic' vs 'traditional research' and what are other categories. I guess u referenced Mit as politechnic. M i right?

@lolvivo8783  I mean schools that are designated as institutes of technology, or are modeled in the French polytechnique  or grandes écoles tradition of education. I'm referring specifically to institutions that offer highly specialized educations in mostly, but not exclusively, technical subjects. The California Institute of Technology (or Caltech) is another example (Caltech was originally named the Polytechnic Institute).  Comparing an institute of technology to a traditional liberal arts school makes no sense. They employ vastly different methods of teaching and are rooted in vastly different traditions of education.   MIT vs Caltech is an apt comparison, as is Harvard vs Columbia. You could even compare Harvard to the Public Ivies. But comparing Harvard to MIT is more of a question of what you want to get out of education, and/or what you want to do in life, rather than which is the "better" or "harder" school.

@themaskedman221    Thanks i did know that to claim as University u ought to have all branches of education. And 'tech' and 'polytech' institutes generally specialised in their domain - sort of applied science and therefore publish research in those narrow domains. However, thanks to u i got to know a bit more on their historical categorisation and genesis. Are there more categories? Does modern educational organisation have french roots? Where do i read more?

@lolvivo8783  Not just every branch of education, but a certain number of courses on offer per branch to qualify as a university.   In the US, the polytechnic tradition has French roots; the rest stem from the liberal arts tradition that was part of a classical education for many centuries in Western Europe. But these days, even the traditional liberal arts schools (like Harvard) offer specialization.
